title: 'I don't understand why they turned it down' - Communities Secretary on North East devolution
text:
'I don't understand why they turned it down' - Communities Secretary on North East devolution 05:00, 5 Oct 2016 By Jonathan Walker Communities Secretary Sajid Javid tells the Chronicle he is talking to three North East councils about a fresh devolution deal Share Get daily news by email John Phillips/PA Wire Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government, Sajid Javid 
Talks on a new North East devolution deal have begun, Local Government Secretary Sajid Javid has confirmed. 
But only Newcastle, Northumberland and North Tyneside are involved in the discussions - because the original North East deal between the Government and seven North East councils is “dead”. 
Mr Javid said it was “too early to say” whether the three authorities north of the Tyne could have their own elected mayor. 
The Government had been backing proposals for a North East Combined Authority with a directly-elected mayor and funding of £30 million a year over 30 years as well as the power to run some local services such as buses. 
But it was scrapped after the four leaders of Gateshead, Sunderland, Durham and South Tyneside councils voted not to go ahead unless they received more reassurances from the government over funding after the Brexit vote. 
Speaking to the Chronicle at the Conservative conference in Birmingham, Mr Javid said the original deal with the seven local authorities, including Newcastle, Northumberland and North Tyneside, was no longer an option. Read More 
“And it’s dead because the majority of local leaders voted against it. 
“I don’t really understand why. 
“Because what they offered was, do you want lots more money to spend as you wish locally on infrastructure and development, and do you want lots more powers? And they said no. 
“It’s the first region that’s said no to such an invitation. 
“And since then it’s been quite clear what the reaction has been from local businesses, local investors, asking why would you say ‘no’ to something that’s going to lead to more jobs and growth? 
“And that’s for them to explain why they said no.” 
However, a separate deal with the three councils that backed devolution was under discussion, he said. 
“There are three of the seven that wanted this deal, but they understand you needed a majority to go forward. 
“So they’ve approached us and said ‘look, can we talk about another deal?’ And we are discussing with them. 
“The deal would be very different and it will be on a very different timeframe. We’ve said we are happy to look at and discuss other options, but it is very early days.” Read More Council chiefs hold devolution talks with Whitehall - but what's the latest for the North East deal? 
Asked if Newcastle, Northumberland and North Tyneside could have their own mayor, he said it was possible but a mayor might not be suitable for a smaller area. 
“I’m not ruling anything out but it’s too early to say what a deal could look like. 
“To have a mayor, you need a workable economic zone. And I don’t think we’ve done enough work on that yet. But we are very open to discussions.”
